title: 113_hr3202
content: The Act is titled the "Essential Transportation Worker Identification Credential Assessment Act" and includes a comprehensive security assessment of the Transportation Security Card Program. The Secretary of Homeland Security must provide a comprehensive assessment of the transportation security card program's effectiveness in enhancing security for regulated facilities and vessels to specific committees and the Comptroller General within a year of the Act's enactment. The assessment will be conducted by a national laboratory or a maritime security university-based center with expertise in maritime security. The Secretary of Homeland Security must conduct a comprehensive assessment of the transportation security card program's effectiveness in addressing security risks in the maritime environment. A corrective action plan must be submitted to relevant committees within 60 days of the assessment. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a corrective action plan to the Senate Commerce, Science, and Transportation Committee within 60 days of assessing the transportation security card program. The plan may include programmatic reforms, regulatory revisions, or legislative proposals and will be considered in any Department rule-making related to the program. The Comptroller General will review the plan within 120 days to assess its implementation of recommendations from national laboratories or maritime security centers and the Comptroller. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a corrective action plan to relevant committees within 60 days of assessing the transportation security card program. The plan will be reviewed by the Comptroller General to assess its implementation of recommendations before the issuance of final rules requiring the use of transportation security card readers. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a corrective action plan to relevant committees within 60 days of assessing the transportation security card program. The plan will be reviewed by the Comptroller General to assess its implementation of recommendations before the issuance of final rules requiring the use of transportation security card readers. The Senate committee must confirm that the submission is in line with the Comptroller General's recommendations and the Secretary must update the list of compatible transportation security card readers. This requirement does not apply to the final rule on TWIC-Reader Requirements issued by the Coast Guard in 2013. The Comptroller General will oversee the implementation of the corrective action plan within 18 months. Every six months for 3 years after the issuance of the corrective action plan, the Comptroller General will report to relevant committees on the implementation of the plan. No additional funds are authorized for this Act and its amendments, using existing available amounts.
